posts.com:
/lit/ is for the discussion of literature, specifically books (fiction & non-fiction), short stories, poetry, creative writing, etc. If you want to discuss history, religion, or the humanities, go to /his/. If you want to discuss politics, go to /pol/. Philosophical discussion can go on either /lit/ or /his/, but those discussions of philosophy that take place on /lit/ should be based around specific philosophical works to which posters can refer.

Check the wiki, the catalog, and the archive before asking for advice or recommendations, and please refrain from starting new threads for questions that can be answered by a search engine.

/lit/ is a slow board! Please take the time to read what others have written, and try to make thoughtful, well-written posts of your own. Bump replies are not necessary.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Meditation and or brute forcing myself into a hyperfixated state can be done without medication, it just takes persistence to keep returning to the task at hand when distracted and allowing other impulses to float by without engaging them. Eventually the impulses stop, or at least quiet down.
Adderall removes the struggling step and lets me get hyperfocused on something instantly, problem is that I can still end up fixated on the wrong thing if I'm not careful and end up wasting time anyways. Doesn't happen much now, but I still remember the first time it happened when I meant to spend a small amount of time drawing and then to read/study, but ended up spending all day drawing and not having a meal until evening.
Also, using amphetamines is similar to the symbiote in Raimi's Spiderman 3. When taken regularly for extended periods of time it definitely causes a noticable boost in confidence, but also increases combativeness and sets you on edge a bit. Can be kind of fun at first, it's a subtle drunkenness, but you don't want to have the smacking your ex-girlfriend in a seedy jazz club moment.
Low-dose psychedelics (weed) when taken in small amounts can also help, but I've found that it's too inconsistent in terms of how it affects me to be helpful. A couple hits one day set me in the right space to be mellowed out a bit and easily immerse myself in something, but on another day made me an anxious wreck or a lazy hedonistic couch-potato.
Moderate alcohol use can also help with focus in my experience, and is easier to know your limits with than DUDE WEED, but isn't a good thing to make a habit or a tool (same goes for weed).
Looping back to the start, I recommend meditation more than substances for reading. Spending a good 15 minutes in silence and solitude intentionally allowing distractions that tug at you to pass by will put you in a state of clarity and focus that is superior to any a substance provides.

>>21598154
Sure. It can easily be gleaned as a derived consequence from the english utilitarians, Bentham and Mill being the usual suspects (hence why Nietzsche wrote that man does not strive for happiness, only the Englishman does). If the greeks are more your speed, you could make a (shitty) case that Epicurus might suggest coomerdom.

If your intention is to understand the "coomer grindset" >>21598174, you should seek out books that investigate the same fundamental impulses and drives as the coomer has - so philosophy might be useful, but so would literature that does the same. In order to pursue this, you must realize that the pornography and masturbation are incidental consequences of something more primordial. Modern coomerdom is the historically contingent result of something more fundamental in the human spirit, and that's where you have to go to find a proper answer.

"The french" were suggested initially, and while Houllebecq's works certainly deal with an ultimately pornographic spirit, he does not at all promote it, but meditates on the ennui of it - that's not what you're seeking, but we are in the right territory. I'd recommend Joris-Karl Huysmans' À Rebours, which is an unapologetic promotion of surrendering to the pure superficiality of the decadent aesthete life, which is the essence of pornography.

Other suggestions would be the initial A-part of Kierkegaard's Either/Or, for while the aesthete, A, is supposedly "refuted" by the bourgeois Assessor Willhelm in the B-part (very strong cases could be made for Kierkegaard just having a laugh at Hegel's expense in this part and those of his readers who continuously fail to realize the significance of Kierkegaard writing a 400-page treatise on irony), A does present something diabolically compelling, much like Milton's Satan, and much of what he has to say could likewise be seen as a promotion and defense of the pornographic lifestyle.

posts.com:
>>21564359
try "Athenaze", you can even ehm borrow it from the link in the OP if you want to give it a try, these kind of books were made for people to take it slow and comfy if you don't have time constraints
I used it and I'm reading both Thucydides and Homer right now
knowing Latin though does help a lot, but it's not necessary, it will just make the process easier

to simplify it a lot you will learn initially the Greek spoken by Plato in the Athens of the fifth-fourth century, which is the basis of Koine, which largely is a simplified version of it, and it's also a sister dialect to Ionic, which is the base of Homer
once your Attic will be good enough, moving to other dialects won't be too hard, especially Ionic; Homer it's kind of it's own thing, as it's an artificial poetic language whose main challenge is really the lexicon not so much the odd forms which you get used to fairly easily

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21584684
>I've heard of a Greek who learned Ancient Greek by working gradually backward in time.
This method is actually the best way to learn any ancient language and it's not up for debate in a technical sense. The problem is that even though the period from when you start something like Epic Greek to the point that you can understand it fluently is much shorter, the overall study time it takes you to master Modern Greek, then Byzantine, then Koine, Attic, etc before you get to Homer will be a grueling grind if you don't actually give a fuck about modern Greece or Byzantium and you just wanted to read the Illiad and Odyssey. So you basically have the option of studying Ancient Greek upfront and taking maybe 3-5 years to understand it fluently or going backwards in time over 3-5 years and only needing a few months towards the end to grasp Homer. But it still can take the same amount of time. But at least with the former you are spending all that time on the thing that you are actually interested in.

The only thing that would make me do this approach would be if near native comprehension was my #1 goal above all else. If that's your goal, this method is without a doubt the way to go. Otherwise, I wouldn't bother.

Nobody seems to notice this but Peterson's cognitive binary (Order/Chaos) replaces Jung's (Logos/Eros) but he acts like Jung never had one. Eros is unity/connection and Logos is multiplicity/discrimination; this binary works because all phenomena manifests as a unity which contains multiplicity. This can easily be demonstrated with the example of an inch: a unit of distance such as an inch exists as a span between zero and one, and within that span you can create infinite decimal subdivisions but you can never escape the fact that in order to have the phenomena even numerically there has to be a unity that contains multiplicity. This is what Aristotle said about time and what Kant described when he said "all bodies are extended".
When Logos/Eros is replaced with Order/Chaos the feminine category switches from connection to something that can only be compared to disconnection. Order by itself simply refers to discrimination but that creates a problem being that discrimination only creates a category when unity contains it, otherwise the discrimination functions as a solution to chaos (which is why Peterson said he believes the purpose of the left hemisphere is to prevent the right hemisphere from having to turn on, as he theorizes that the role of the right hemisphere is to detect anomaly which the left tries to integrate). The result is discrimination ad infinitum which results in the identity/phenomena being atomized into obliteration which is the same problem Guenon identified with materialism and individualism in Crisis of the Modern World. Identities are dependent on unity (group) and individualism nullifies identity by assuming multiplicity is dominant which de facto rejects group identity.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21599610
>him again
you don't need any special paint, just use a gloss paint, prime first and do a few coats to seal it up well. Oil base is a bit better but not a huge deal here. You can also just use poly. Anything gloss, the goal is to make sure you have a surface which stuff which mold can grow can not stick too and if it does you can just wipe it off along with the mold.

A light sanding never hurts and is the safest path when unsure, just make sure to remove ALL sanding dust before painting.

Anti-mold paints are largely a gimmick, does not prevent something sticking to it which mold can grow on, it will kill any mold on the surface before painting and the paint itself will not mold but any oil base paint will probably do just as well if not better because of the solvents and creating a better seal.

>>21584316
I re-read these about half a decade ago after noticing the wiki summary was full of terms I'd never expect to see used for children's books:
>"They have been classified as postmodern and metafictional writing, with the plot evolution throughout the later novels being cited as an exploration of the psychological process of transition from the idyllic innocence of childhood to the moral complexity of maturity. Likewise, the final installments of the series are also acknowledged for their escalatingly intricate ethical ambiguity toward philosophical ambivalence"

I was really amazed how much slipped by me as a kid. Though it starts as standard plot-fronting genre fiction, by the time you reach 'The End' it pretty much becomes a full-on existentialist novel, deconstructing the idea of a mystery, coincidence, and answer, a protagonist, antagonist, and side character, etc. It's also steeped in a weird miasma of cultural symbolism ranging from The Odyssey to Paradise Lost to Heart of Darkness. The Baudelaire's ascension to moral agency is literally capped off with a snake offering Violet a forbidden apple to save her life
I'm not at all surprised I saw so many people who read it as kids complain that 'the ending didn't make sense' or that 'he didn't answer anything'

Not that there’s any point arguing against Wikipedia, but for me it’s always come across as a modernist children’s book rather than post-modern. You have these exceptionally gifted children thrown into a world full of idiocy, bureaucracy, dogmatism and evil- they are the glimmers of the light of reason in a modern dark age. Of course, by the end of the series the children are not unimpeachable- but then again, the modernist project was also not without its own ethical crises (WWI, WWII, etc.).

And when I talk about pre-eminence, what I really mean is that if you look at the Roman state, there was no separation of the religious or the legal functions as they pertained to politics. A Roman aristocrat could be a legislator and prosecutor, a priest, an executive, and a military commander all in one lifetime. In the medieval state, medieval noble could be political, and also a military officer, a legislator, a judge, or a priest but not all of them. Priesthood, in particular, was a separate vocation taken for life and played a pre-eminent role in what we call politics. And so by demarcating these things - the political, the theological, and the legal, we set the precedent for interchanging them to set up governance of religion, governance of laws, etc. liberalism very much favors governance of the law. When we say “rule of law” we mean it literally. The liberal sovereign is the law and lawyers are the nobles. De Tocqueville noted this in Democracy in America.

I've corresponded with someone who studied under Schmitt scholars who have gone to China for conferences with academics there who have worked on Schmitt, and what I was told -- about why there has been interest in him there -- is that much of his work deals with some shortcomings of the liberal tradition, and China (this was around 10 years ago when you see a lot of Schmitt scholarship in China, not sure if there's as much now) was opening up a bit and exploring liberalism, like seeing what they could learn from it. The Chinese are very much about taking things they think will work for them from other systems and dropping what they don't like.

What's important here is that Schmitt's work doesn't try to criticize an "authoritarian" system like what China has when discussing liberalism, as a lot of political theory writing about liberalism does. And the two most important concepts in Schmitt, the concept of the political and the state of exception, are interesting to them. But I don't see those things as inherently "left" or "right" as others ITT have said. In the West, it's often the right which has been interested in Schmitt, because you have to ask yourself who in the 70s/80s was interested in looking into the works of a guy who was in the Nazi Party, and they tended to be weird conservative types. But in fact there have been oddball Marxist academics in the West who have too.

If I may be allowed to cite a passage that has stayed with me rather than a whole book, this is Anthony Trollope on the friendzone (Ralph the Heir, 1871):

>Clarissa had given thrice that answer, which of all answers is the most grievous to the true-hearted lover. "She felt for him unbounded esteem, and would always regard him as a friend." A short decided negative, or a doubtful no, or even an indignant repulse, may be changed,—may give way to second convictions, or to better acquaintance, or to altered circumstances, or even simply to perseverance. But an assurance of esteem and friendship means, and only can mean, that the lady regards her lover as she might do some old uncle or patriarchal family connection, whom, after a fashion, she loves, but who can never be to her the one creature to be worshipped above all others.

Recs for my first Trollope read?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21599517
Well, he has two main series of books that follow on from each other. The Chronicles of Barsetshire are comfy books set in a cathedral town, covering the Church politics and rural aristocracy of the area. Personally, I thought that 'The Warden', 'Barchester Towers', and 'The Last Chronicle of Barset' were very good, 'Doctor Thorne', 'Framley Parsonage' and 'The Small House at Allington' were no more than pleasant filler. 'Barchester Towers' is one of the funniest satires I have ever read, but three books out of six is not a brilliant hit-rate for the modern, time-starved reader.

The Palliser novels all mix political satire with portraits of middle to upper class social life, showing how the hypocrisies of one bleed into the other. I think this is of more interest to the modern reader, at least it was to me. This is also a series of six books, and I would recommend all six. The series starts with 'Can You Forgive Her?', which is among my favourite Trollope novels and would probably be my recommendation for a starting point.

I haven't read all the standalone novels, of which there are very many, but they vary quite considerably in quality. What you get out of them depends on your interest in the core themes. Trollope books almost invariably juxtapose two contrasting themes: Ralph the Heir is about bastardy and wasted privilege; Orley Farm is about inheritance and marriage; The Claverings is about jealousy and marriage; and so on. The standout for me among the standalones is 'The Way We Live Now', which is about the rapacity of international finance and the fecklessness and timidity of the British to let it overtake them. Cracking read, but in my view too long and complex to take on first.

Hope you give him a try! He's very different from Dickens, but in my view absolutely no less skilled as a novelist.

posts.com:
So I have been thinking about this book. Its form and execution mainly and which tradition of writing does it fit in. In the Novel form, Dostoevsky and Thomas Mann, who was influenced by Dosto, are obvious comparisons. But the form of the conversation is quite different from Dosto and Mann. It has been compared to Sunset Limited but again the form that the conversation takes in Sunset limited is also quite different, and more abjectly Dostoevskian.

McCarthy might have revived and replenished Socratic dialogues for fiction. Dr. Cohen can't follow Alicia and it is precisely because he can't follow her or offer anything in the way of intellectual simulation is what shapes the conversation in Stella Maris. The book is 190 pages of 'Dialogues with the self'. The therapist just provides the frame for the conversation to begin but as it progresses and deep into the book, Alicia and her mind unravels. McCarthy is possibly nodding at the history of western literature, which began proper with greek plays and its most modern renditions have been dominated by the solipsistic internal monologue/stream of consciousness. Alicia is a solipsist herself, and the confessional turn her rambles take on later into the book as opposed to the more balanced beginning is possibly an allegory for the evolving form of literature. The kind of conversation that McCarthy has become known for is also much more flexible in integrating philosophy given its origins in philosophy.

Moreover, Alicia isn't perfectly reliable, as is visible after reading The Passenger. Her digressions on the nature of hallucinations have tones of metafiction, also in the fact that we are not meant to be omnipresent passive observers of the fictive dream, a frame used by most works of realism, but rather acknowledged listeners of the tapes of her therapy sessions. The reader has been, however marginally, included in the book.

I think Stella Maris is the next step in the evolution of confessional literature, pioneered by Dostoevsky and has included among its ranks writers like kafka, Celine, Miller, Beckett etc. Modern autofiction is also a strand from this same tradition. The book begins with a normal dialogic form but soon progresses into philosophical treatise and rambling monologues, it is the perfect setup and aesthetic to accomodate organically all the various strands of traditions gone before.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21596908
It also explores a new, untapped dynamic. Internal monologue/first person narration provides a different approach because the narrator and the reader are always separated by the pages and the narrative is an exercise in solipsism because we are, in a way, in the narrator's head, while Joycean/Faulknerian Streams relegates the reader to passive unintended listeners of thoughts. But here the narrator's direct listener is sitting with her forcing her to modulate herself and her thoughts. The Narrator is caught between two worlds due to the length and form of the conversation. McCarthy's form rescues Alicia from her own solipsism momentarily by providing a laconic listener, a witness. Cohen can't change her mind or even begin to reason with her, but it at least allows Alicia to listen to her own self. The witness changes the nature of the event even as he witnesses it, which is probably the foundational outlook of the two sibling novels.

It is quite amazing what McCarthy has done even if the weirdities are only felt and are not easily recognizable. I imagine we will see a lot of avant garde stuff using such a premise and form in the future. Would be a horrible waste if we don't.

You should read more and work on analyzing narrative structure, Socratic dialog never left literature and is constantly being reworked into new ways. Even the Socratic dialog as dialog with self is common, we see it all over stream of consciousness works as you mentioned, removing the monologue from the characters head is not exactly revolutionary and we see this very thing done in works which alternate between stream of consciousness and other perspectives. This is essentially the structure of IJ, it just has multiple characters and the narrator all going through it at the same time and the plot in place of Dr Cohen.

You need to look more at function, McCarthy at best just went more literal with a common technique, he adds his own touch but is not revolutionizing anything and ultimately has made this extreme off limits for everyone for a few decades at least since anyone who does it will be viewed as an impersonator because of his standing.

>>21599249
Nigga, you literally don't have any idea what you are talking about.

Your argument is fundamentally wrong, even looking past the analogy. You are mischaracterizing Socratic Dialogues.

Socratic Dialogues have a very specific setup. There is the philosopher/rambler and the listener/yes-man. It is NOT a debate. The yes-man/listener only interjects to steer the conversation, he is not there to provide opposition. Dr. Cohen fits the bills to a tee.

The protagonist/antagonist dynamic even as an analogy fits Dostoevsky's Dialogic novels like TBK, where the dialogues are meant more as religio-philosophical debates. In McCarthy's oeuvre only Sunset limited is of this type.

You literally don't even understand what characterizes Socratic dialogues yet you are arguing and asking people to prove you wrong. What is wrong with you? If this is not sophistry then what is?

posts.com:
We had been together for about 4 months at this point. We were very in love with each other. Our happines was cut a bit short because I had to go serve my mandatory conscription that summer. She wept so much the day she dropped me of at the garrison and we wouldn't see each other for a few weeks. We had slept together every day for the past four months, so it was hard especially for her.

Two weeks passed with me going through all the basics. It was tiring, but every single evening I called her so we could talk and be together again. After those two weeks we had our first "vacation" which would last a few days.

The day before the vacation, during the free time we had in the evening, I went outside into the hot July air. I had a plan, you see. I was going to pick my girl pretty flowers that I had seen inside the garrison area. Then, when we would walk out of the gates where she was to be waiting for me, I would hand her my bouquet. She would love it. She deserved it. So, I gathered the prettiest flowers I could.

The next day dawned. Two weeks in the military and it was very needed to see the outside world already even if I didn't have a girl waiting for me anxiously. Before we were allowed to leave some officers were to inspect our rooms and personal closets so that everything looked nice and soldierly. I had hid my bouquet behind all the junk.

The room I was in passed the test on the first try. Soon we would all get to go outside and form into ranks so the commander of our unit could give us a little "vacation speech" as it is called. Then we would be allowed to march outside of the gates.

As we rushed outside, I held my bouquet of flowers in my hand. I went into the last row, hoping that some officer wouldn't question my odd equipment. No-one did. When the commander finished, we gave one final salute and then our formation was ordered to turn right. Suddendly I was in the front row, holding a bouquet of flowers!

We marched in an orderly fashion towards our freedom. As we got closer our discipline was allowed to break and soon we started running. I ran in the front, holding my flowers.

And there she was. Waiting for me in her blood red dress beyond the gates. Her auburn hair glowing in the bright July sun. My prize, my love. I ran past the checkpoint, threw my bag on the ground so I could hug her and we embraced each other. I gave her the flowers, and her reaction was as anticipated. I could have cried of happiness, but that's not soldierly.

At home she gave me a gift in return: a medallion with a picture of us inside. The best gift I ever had. Then she lifted her dress and showed the lingerie she was wearing, and you can imagine what happened next. We had not seen each other for two weeks, after all.

This all happened in another time and space. She left me yesterday. I came home from uni to a dark and empty apartment. She had packed while I had been away. The medallion was gone too.

All I wanted was to say my final farewell to you.

How do you start writing a poem, and how long does it take you to write 4-8 lines? I have recently started to (attempt to) write a weekly poem for my wife, despite having very little experience in the field, and my process so far is as follows:
>decide on an image I want to use as a "theme", like the first warm sunny day after winter
>make what I as an amateur have dubbed the "heart" of the poem, meaning a central rhyme that I will then build the rest of the poem around
>add sentences around this "heart" of the poem until it makes me cringe
>remove what I can until I cringe a little less

So far, I have not given my wife any of the poems as they all make me feel like a pseud, but I have at least taken a step toward being the person I want to be.

What is your process for writing poetry?

I’m a bi male. I’ve written a hundred poems in my 20 years of romance. When I first started I let my heart tell the pen what to do. I would write would write without caring about what I wrote and just gave it to her. She would ask me about stuff. I was in school was I started so I was inundated by text reading and other studies so I’m sure some of that bleed over. Eventually I could write around a theme. I think you have to earn theme poems. I would start with the one fish two fish red fish blue fish style poems to get accustomed to just writing poems. This is a purely creative venture. I’m sure you can get taught or learn what a poem is or how it’s constructed but until you take the time to get your poem kill count up it will always be a learning lesson. I can write a poem in minutes and listen to my heart or I spend a little more time to construct a themed poem which would take me maybe 8 hrs of time toying around with it. I hope this helps from my anecdote.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I read one page per day. I first read it while I eat my grape fruit and wait for my oatmeal to cook. While eating my oatmeal i consider that page and then I read that page a second time. While I shower I consider the page in context to the previous page and as I dry myself and dress for the day I consider it in context to the context explored in the previous days shower. As I drink my coffee I copy the page out into a sheet of parchment paper which I then wrap my sandwich in. At this point I forget about my reading and focus on the days tasks until lunch. During lunch I intently study my sandwich's wrapper and the various edits made by a bit of mayo, a stray sprout or a crease in the paper, exploring the new contexts they suggest until I have lost all sense of the original page. Once again I forget about the page and return to the days activities until I return home for the night. Once home I prepare my dinner and season it by reading the page aloud over my meal. I retain very little of this reading of the page and find that the sandwich's editting still occupies my mind. As I eat my food well seasoned with the words of the page it returns to me a word at a time but never in the proper order. I carefully chew each word until I have found its proper place, the I's are most difficult and one can never really be sure if they got the right 'I' in the right place, especially troublesome with dialog. After dinner I go for a walk to help with digestion and prepare my mind for sleep. Before bed I read the page a final time. I sleep soundly.

posts.com:
>thread edition
Many famous writers saw little or no success in their lifetimes.
Philip K. Dick struggled his entire life, despite writing 44 novels and 125 short stories. He only saw real money after selling the movie rights to "Do Androids Dream Of Electric Sheep", which became "Blade Runner". Sadly, he passed away before he could enjoy his success. But his children are billionaires.
Herman Melville only sold a few thousand copies of "Moby Dick" in his lifetime. He tried to follow up with something more ribald and popular, but that didn't do so well either. He relied on day jobs handed out to him by patrons and other fans of his work. It wasn't until the 100th anniversary of his birth when his work was reappraised, far too late to be of any good to him.
Marcel Proust couldn't find a publisher for the 1st volume of "In Search Of Lost Time", so he self-published it. That was a much more expensive and risky proposition in those days.
These days, thanks to the double-edge sword of Amazon publishing, one can get published easily, but it's nearly impossible to stand out among the flood of content.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>21596947
Way too much filtering. You're stating what the character sees, feels, thinks. If you just describe the world and what's happening, the reader will assume that the character can see it too.

The pulp formula is to write in Motive-Reaction units. First you write the motive, what happens. Then you write how the character reacts, what they sense, what they think, what they say -- in that order.

You really should read >>21590193 if you want to write genre fiction.

>It's not that Bob thinks they don't exist. More probably, Bob, like Khakheperessenb or Brackman's Madison Avenue junior executives, is acutely aware that many of his phrases are necessarily prefabricated, and he does not want to be thought uncool. posts.com:
>>21597161
>I feel like I honestly did at the very least an average job of this.
We all feel that. That's what makes editing so hard.

>But could you maybe help me put by giving an example from m6 story where you feel I do what you're saying in a detrimental way?
> Seeing no end to the path, Satoræ starts to fear they may have to spend the night in the woods.
With no end to the path, Satorae might not escape these woods before nightfall.
>Realizing no one is here, the small flicker of hope they had that perhaps Nebulosa or the Bhillana had left a guide here to aid them fades away.
The woods were empty. No one was here to offer help. Neb had left no guides out of the wilderness, and Bhil had left no signs marking a path to safety.

It's fine on occasion, but go through your chapter and count up every time your verb is think, feel, look, remembered, recalled, know, realize or some similar word. It's basically ever sentence. Because of that, nothing is happening in your story. It's just a guy looking at stuff.

The second, related problem is flat out stating what the character feels. They feel tired. They feel confused. They feel nervous. It's dull and clumsy. Again, you get away with that sometimes, but not over and over again. Don't tell me the character is nervous, write a scene about spooky trees or whatever and then say they hold their breath while slowly drawing their sword. Leave something for the reader figure out.

All in all, you need to get out of the character's head and into the world. Write about things happening to the character. Think of them as a ping pong ball for you to hit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21597599
>1 main character but 3 who are important
They can be important to your plot without being equally as important to the reader. Personally, I'd write short stories about the non-protagonist characters to solidify their place in the story without having it included in the main body of work, which should be focused on its protagonist. Then, I'd write the story you wish to tell from the protagonist's perspective. Once you're finished, you can try to incorporate your short stories into the novel by giving each a dedicated chapter, no more, no less. If they cameo throughout the work, that's fine, just don't forget who the focus is on.

How bad is the whole "starting in the middle" cliche? How far can you go with that? For example a continuous introductory story arc (if a novel is divided in several parts) starts off with a chapter from near the end of it. This seems okay, first there is a surprising twist to a chapter, that wouldn't exist if the story was chronologically consistent. And this entire chapter acts as a mystery to be figured out and a promise of an original plot. Overall it is a solid one. But let's assume that we go too far and throw a chapter from the middle of a story that follows the introductory story arc. I see that there can be a lot of confusion for a reader and they can get tired of reading and not getting the conclusion.

Well, basically I have an outline of a story with two first parts more developed. There is a part where main characters get introduced, the setting and goals are declared and a reader will be completely able to figure out things based on their common knowledge of the genre. And there is a second part that includes some trickery and acting with mystery characters and contains this special short chapter. I wonder if I should start with the introduction first, put the special chapter after it and then follow with the second part. Read the first bit of it.
It may simply not be for me. It seems this is for a rather nich audience, but it comes off as a bit tryhard anyway. Doesn't give anything to latch onto and make me care about what's happening. Does not really draw intrigue about whatever mysterious circumstance this ambiguous character has either.
"Bizzare sensation" is pretty bad. It's one of those phrases that accomplishes nothing as a bizarre sensation can mean anything. So, bad to have that right in the first sentence.
"Immeasurable distance" has the same problem.
Same as "they feel as time slows to a near stop"
You seem to favor these un-commital phrases. It's not being ambiguous; it comes off as if you don't know how to describe it, so you are attempting to hide that fact by trying to sound cool and mysterious

Perhaps you are going about it the wrong way, though. Maybe start with a more disconnected view from the narration (while also using more useful phrases) something like,
>The creature steps through the gate. Instantly they are blinded by white light as their body is stretched like a dry-rotted rubberband, then, all at once, snapped back together. Disoriented, they reach for the wall, feeling nausea wash over them.

You know, not exactly like that, I wrote that in like 2 seconds, but you get the idea. Use phrases that actually show the reader something.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I've read a lot on the topic. It's a subject beset by an epidemic of grifters, appeals to fake authority, etc. Forgeries are justified by magic involving deception or self-deception. Most mystical traditions are inexorably bound up in the religions that spawned them and don't make sense out of context.

I would start with the Oxford guide edited by Magee, since it is a rare, sober, scholarly survey of the field. Then see which tradition interests you most and try to read more.

The Great Courses has a solid course on Gnosticism. Their course on mysticism is somewhat shallow, but a decent overview.

Schloem is great on Kabbalah.

Magee's book on Hegel is a bad take on Hegel in that its thesis is way too strong and it cherry picks to support it, but is actually a good summary of esoterica in the Western tradition and linkages to more formal systems of thought.

For actual mystical texts, I thought Meditations on the Tarot was better than most.

Recommendations? Start here, go anywhere. But most importantly: M E D I T A T E & P R A C T I C E

PS: Consider studying Tarot as well! While contemporary tarot attributions are considered by most scholars nowadays to be ahistorical, they nevertheless function as a powerful esoteric / occult memnonic technique. I would suggest starting your tarot study with Mystical Origins of the Tarot for a relatively scholarly history with a good mix of theory and practice. Another fun Tarot book is Tomberg's Meditations on the Tarot, it's not really occult per se altho certainly esoteric but nevertheless it remains an excellent example of the continuing cross-pollination between occult and mainstream threads of theology and philosophy as well as the ongoing dialogue of occident and orient and esoteric and exoteric which will also become familiar to you if you follow this list.

When I first got into literature, like “literary” books, I was into more difficult books. I got my foot in the door with the postmodern crowd and more often than not I was reading a door stopper. As I’ve gotten older, difficult novels appeal to me less and less, and I am more hesitant when a novel is above ~700 pages. I’ve thought about this development in my reading habit some and I can’t quite make sense of it. I don’t know if I was a pseud in the beginning, or I realized there is a lot out there that I want to read and I value my time more than I used to. Maybe it’s something else though. I have no issue with monstrous autobiographies and journals, and some easier longer works like Dickens. I also think what I look for in a book has greatly changed. In the beginning I wanted to be challenged and see the limits of technical writing stretched to the limit. Now, what I look for in a book is it’s “spirit”, message, what I take in subconsciously, or entertainment. Sorry for the blog post but I’m always curious about readers’ progressions.

I don't think Wagner was conservative. The ring cycle, the progression from Wotan to Siegmund to Siegfried, and the two "lawful" unions of the cycle, that is, Hunding's, and Siegfried's wedding with Gutrune, tells us that Wagner does not value the rule of law, (and perhaps traditional morality) that he deems it shabby. Likewise, Wotan's role and especially Gunther's seem to suggest a complete lack of faith in politics and politicians. Wagner is apolitical, he values freedom, courage, and love, and not some two-bit political party.

>>21599231
It is. He wrote in 1933:

>What should our attitude be towards Wagner? Perhaps we should cast him aside, since he is a reactionary? Perhaps we should say: Only from here to here? And accept the first Wagner uncritically, forgetting how immature he was, how many admixtures there were? Or should we discard the second Wagner completely, forgetting the powerful music, the passionate emotions, the shining artistry of this genius, a prisoner of reaction?

>None of this is right. We would never be forgiven if we did not know how to analyse, if we would have cast away the rich gold ore simply because, at first glance, it contained very few grains of gold. We would never have been forgiven if we had accepted at face value a piece of impure metal, corroded from within. Our analysis cannot manipulate masters and opuses as a whole. We must delve deeper. An understanding of Wagner from a socialist point of view is a very intricate affair. Woe to him who impoverishes the world by crossing out Wagner’s name with a censor’s pencil. Woe to him who would let this cunning magician, this talent, tainted by an evil disease, into our camp and, as in Heine’s famous poem, would let the plague-stricken titan press his lips against the face of young proletarian culture.

[...]

>Wagner’s music is shrouded in a magnificent cloak. The cloaks of the outstanding composers of pathétique music after Wagner are more majestic still, but no longer does the goddess who found shelter beneath Wagner’s cloak abide with them. Wagner has bequeathed this wealth, this seriousness, and, in the sense of musical ideas, this meaningfulness to future centuries.

>Likewise, the combination of a philosopher-musician and a philosopher-poet, and a dramatist at that, has apparently made him the greatest proponent of the true union of music and literature. And we need this, too. We will need this very, very much.

>Wagner could at times channel his exalted musical and dramatic force to serve ideas that were wrong and even harmful, thus making this great power poisonous, but he never demeaned it to become a reflection of the petty, he never debased it to the level of the trivial or the casual.

>No matter if he depicted love or vicious hate, greed, power-madness, or a flight towards freedom, etc. – he portrayed them all in great, commanding images and raised them to such generalisations as to make the emotions he described all-meaningful. This ability to raise art, to raise the theatre to such great heights and artistic abstraction – but abstraction that is not emaciated, that encompasses the concrete, summing it up and making it understandable and significant – this is an ability that we, too, need, and we possess it in a very small measure, which can be proved, firstly, by the fact that our poets and composers have not yet been able to produce a major opera about our revolutionary passions, our world struggle.
https://www.marxists.org/archive/lunachar/1933/wagner.htm

A decade or so later, he started writing and publishing again under the name of his illiterate plebian manservant. He went on to become the greatest playwright of his generation, all while effectively pretending to be dead.

>These witnesses testified that Frizer and Marlowe had argued over payment of the bill (now famously known as the 'Reckoning') exchanging "divers malicious words" while Frizer was sitting at a table between the other two and Marlowe was lying behind him on a couch. >The jury concluded that Frizer acted in self-defence and within a month he was pardoned. Marlowe was buried in an unmarked grave in the churchyard of St. Nicholas, Deptford immediately after the inquest, on 1 June 1593.
>The other witness, Nicholas Skeres, had for many years acted as a confidence trickster, drawing young men into the clutches of people in the money-lending racket, including Marlowe's apparent killer, Ingram Frizer, with whom he was engaged in such a swindle.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Many German expressionists died in the mortar fire of World War I. There was an anticipation among them that the Great War would be an "apocalyptic event" that would destroy the old, decayed, Wilhelministic world and create a new one from its ashes, a rebirth of new values. So they willingly signed up as soldiers, thinking they would die glorious deaths in battle like the people in myths. They didn't anticipate how industrious modern war would be, and got smashed to bits as young men "in storms of steel".
Some expressionists' deaths sticking out to me though are the following: Georg Trakl, who served as a military doctor on the eastern front, tried to shoot himself after all he had witnessed. His remaining friends prevented him from doing so and he was sent to a military hosptial - where he promptly killed himself by overdosing on cocaine.
And then there is Georg Heym, perhaps the greatest poet of German expressionism. He didn't make it to the war. 18 months before it started, he went ice skating with a friend. His friend broke into the ice in the middle of the wilderness. Heym tried to save him, but broke in himself. Woodcutters from a nearby forest allegedly heared him screaming for 20 minutes but were to scared to help him. His corpse was found days later under the ice.
Dying at age 24 to an ice skating incident might not be a particularly "weird" death. But to me it always stuck out. Almost all his contemporaries died in World War I, but the greatest of them died just before to a random accident.

This is precisely what makes Russian literature from the nineteenth century so attractive. The society of that time followed completely different rules than ours. At that time it was not a disgrace to be killed standing upright in a duel, on the contrary, it would be a humiliation to flee and expose your wife, family and name to rumors. Turgenev describes a very similar situation where someone faces a duel with a much younger man to protect his brother's honor. This seems to have been the way to deal with such problems in Russia at that time.

posts.com:
>>21594156

Yes yes yes. Ideally two or three at once. I did it right as a little kid, unlearned it as a young adult, and now I've re-learned it as a slightly more mature adult.

When I was a little kid I'd have two to four books going at any one time. They were simple, yes, but the basic habit was correct: have multiple ideas going on in your head all at once so that you can compare them in various unexpected and useful ways. Then as a teenager I got the general idea of Historical Order, or Linear Progression. Being trapped in the idea that things must be read in a certain order, I scarcely read after college. When I started reading again in my late 20s, I made a point of simply seeking out whatever I felt like reading. A second book, completely unrelated to the first, turned out to have unexpected connections. The same specific thing was found in both books, whatever they might have been at the time. Or other slight neural connections could be made.

When you have two or three books going, "ideas have sex with each other" in your head in way that doesn't happen with only one book. This is the value of bouncing back and forth.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21596886
Terminus Est is commonly translated from the Latin as "This is the end", or literally "It is the end". It can also mean "this is the limit", "this is an end" (due to the lack of the definite article), or "this is the border". However, Severian interprets the phrase to mean "this is the line of division", and Typhon translates it as "this is the place of parting".

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21587172
I think the reason it's said to be literary is because it's so much higher quality than genre fiction in terms of prose and themes, not necessarily that it's as good as literary fiction.
Wolfe never tried to be literary, he just liked writing stories that don't fully reveal themselves until reread, and as a result are very subtle, dense, and generate a lot of discussion because they need to be interpreted.
So in terms of complexity he does things literary authors don't do, but I still don't think he's literary. The biggest difference for me is when I read literature I feel more emotional connection with the characters and it's easier to imagine them as being real people. This isn't Wolfe's fault, it's a consequence of writing fantasy, but it's still a huge contrast that illustrates the line separating literary and genre.
At the end of the day he's pulpy as you said, he doesn't take himself seriously, yet he was very smart and his idea of fun was writing very smart stories, so he was in a class of his own.

>>21595896
Yeah. I was not prepared for how different they would be but still loved both. My biggest issue with the first book is that it is not the second and vise versa. It was brave of Simmons to change the structure so much. In retrospect I don't think there was a better way to do it, although each has its limitations.

I think it works well for the themes of the book. The first book introduces a lot of mysterious elements which are experienced in personal ways, with the personality of the people who encounter them coloring the truth behind them, then the second slowly puts them all together into a bigger rational picture where the difference between science and the supernatural is almost meaningless. It follows the progression from mysticism/paganism towards monotheism, and that Simmons pulled it off without feeling dry or contrived was fucking incredible.

They got flooded with submissions from places that were not anything close to what the editor intended. He got overwhelmed with the whole thing, realized that the time, attention, and money he dedicated to the project had become completely unrewarding and thankless, and so pulled the plug after one final edition.
Also, the vast majority of writers have an inflated perception of the quality and originality of their writing. The reason &amp is so good is because it doesn't take itself so seriously and a lot of the humour comes from a combination of self-loathing, incompetence, cynicism, and it's interspersed with genuinely good pieces of writing. But because it doesn't take itself seriously, the good writing can exist without much pressure.

>>21585429
Dick claims it eerily retold a story from the Book of the Acts of the Apostles in the New Testament which he didn’t know at the time of writing it, as well as, simultaneously, a later event in his own life.

>In his undelivered speech "How to Build a Universe That Doesn't Fall Apart Two Days Later," Dick recounts how in describing an incident at the end of the book (end of chapter 27) to an Episcopalian priest, the priest noted its striking similarity to a scene in the Acts of the Apostles in the Bible. In Dick's book, the police chief, Felix Buckman, meets a black stranger at an all-night gas station, and uncharacteristically makes an emotional connection with him. After handing the stranger a drawing of a heart pierced by an arrow, Buckman flies away, but he quickly returns and hugs the stranger, and they strike up a friendly conversation. In Acts Chapter 8, the disciple Philip meets an Ethiopian eunuch (a black man) sitting in a chariot, to whom he explains a passage from the Book of Isaiah, and then converts him to Christianity.

>Dick further notes that eight years after writing the book, he himself uncharacteristically came to the aid of a black stranger who had run out of gas. After giving the man some money and then driving away, he returned to help the man reach a gas station. Dick was then struck by the similarity between this incident and that described in his book.

Taverner’s dream scene was also inspired by his own dream. He also claims it prophetically, and unbeknownst to him at the time, prefigured the United States becoming a totalitarian police state.

>Dick also recounts an unusual dream he had when writing the book, and how he felt compelled to get it into the text of the novel.[7][8] Years later, he came to interpret this dream as the key to understanding the real meaning of the story, stating:

Deciphered, my novel tells a quite different story from the surface story (…). The real story is simply this: the return of Christ, now king rather than suffering servant. Judge rather than victim of unfair judgment. Everything is reversed. The core message of my novel, without my knowing it, was a warning to the powerful: You will shortly be judged and condemned.

Reading Dick’s works as a young man, including VALIS and passages of his Exegesis (a monumental and monolithic tome) actually inspired me to become a Phildickian Gnostic Christian. I think he had a genuine experience of cosmic God-consciousness. No, I will not take meds.

I was writing a bigger post then accidentally pressed esc lmao but summing up what I was saying, I've read bit of Bataille but I can't think of any other way to put it than this: the Accursed Share absolutely terrified me because while it is a frightening notion, his economoy of violence and sacrifice also somehow rings true to me.

I'm brazilian and I've felt year after year the immense cathartic feeling bought upon society after 4 days of complete reckless abandon and waste for it's own sake. More and more the few situations where we're allowed this type of catharsis are either completey mediated by capitalism (concerts, festivals, etc. - not that the carnival isn't in it's own way, but it doesn't depend on a capitalist hyperstructure to happen either) or downright criminal (riots, protests and so on), This is making everyone exceedingly neurotic and paralyzed by the possibility of action (any action, not even political or spiritual, just doing something other than what you did yesterday).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Christ-consciousness as a universally manifesting, always-potentially-open-to-suffering-humanity, cosmic God-consciousness.

The piety, love and devotion stressed in religions like Christianity fused with the more cognitive, abstract notion of enlightenment stressed in Eastern traditions like Buddhism, Hinduism and Taoism (yet still with a heart).

Christianity as authentically both literally and symbolically true (open to pious reverence and devotion, and Jungian-type archetypal analysis), the Archetype of Christ as a living, ensouled symbol perpetually recurring in human history, inspiring women and men, God in a Man and a Man in God (and we are also that same Man, without realizing it) — except this authentic Truth (gnosis) of Christianity PKD accepts, seems a slightly different and far more universalist one from what the Church teaches, although this Truth also can shine and glimmer through the Church at times for PKD, as it can throughout other cultures, times, places, even the trash abandoned on the street, sunlight reflected off the gutter, the Episcopal bishop Timothy Archer who has to cope with the implications of the discovery of the Gnostic Zadokite documents, the gentle ribbing at yet degree of respect for New Age pseudo-gurus like Alan Watts in the character of Edgar Barefoot, the empathy box and pseudo-Christian religion of Mercerism in “Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?”

Empathy as a divine impulse. Divine empathy as, hence, a sense of the fusion or communion of one’s heart, mind and soul with the hearts, minds and souls of all the dead, all the living, and all those yet to live, such as through the gateway of Christ, the Alpha and Omega.

A draw to the Gnostic Nag Hammadi tractates, as well as recurring references to Eastern philosophies such as Buddhism and Taoism in his works. Christ as a Bodhisattva, Bodhisattvas as Christ-like figures. Heavy references to Greek philosophy and mysticism, too. The solution to the cyberpunk dystopia being a Christ-or-Buddha-or-Greek-sage-like forbearance.

Pre-Christian Christians, in the vein of Church Father St. Justin Martyr’s virtuous pagans (amongst Greeks before Christ inspired by the Logos, from Heraclitus to Plato) in on it, too.

The Transcendental Teleological Attractor, or Cosmic Event Horizon at the end of time, like the Omega Point of Jesuit theologian Teilhard de Chardin, drawing the entire universe into self-conscious communion with VALIS (Vast Active Living Intelligence System).

A shamanically vibrant, animistic, ensouled pantheistic universe.

An Eliadean hierophany or irruption of the Sacred into the Profane, yet, paradoxically, and with a point of difference from Eliade, such that it lights up even the Profane and the Mundane and reveals that the Sacred was present and veiled amongst the Profane the entire time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
God playing a Divine Game of Hide and Seek, like the Lila (Play) of Brahman in some Hindu theology, yet without the sense of mere whimsicalness, or even
cruelty, that “game” or “play” can imply.

All roads eventually leading to God, so long as the roads are traveled fully.

The Divine Invasion of the Earth to eventually eliminate all suffering and purify humanity already taking place in the form of religious revelations, prophets, sages, saints and messengers sent to us.

Possession by the spirit of Elijah. Angelology. PKD becoming a more pious and believing Christian than most Christians even while being a rank heretic to most.

The coincidentia oppositorum (coincidence of opposites, from Christian theologian Nicholas of Cusa, to Jung, from Heraclitus to Hegel, from the Taoist yin and yang to Jesus in the Gospel of Thomas saying, “When you make the two one and make the inside like the outside and the outside like the inside and the above like the below, and that you might make the male and the female be one and the same, so that the male might not be male nor the female be female, when you make eyes in place of an eye and a hand in place of a hand and a foot in place of a foot, an image in place of an image - then you will enter [the kingdom].”)

“I know it sounds insane, and I can’t even answer all your questions, or theodical problems of Suffering and Evil, but you’d believe it and love God if you had experienced it, too.”

Credo quia absurdum.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Higher spiritual faculties leading to a miraculous transcendence of the barriers of space and time, miraculous healings, prophesying, foresight (his infant son’s undiagnosed almost-fatal hernia revealed to him in a vision).

Visions of extraterrestrial beings, including in dreams. Looking seriously into ancient alien and ancient astronaut theories (the Dogon people of Mali in West Africa and their impossible astronomical knowledge of the Sirius A and B double-star system).

This being so absurd even PKD begins to doubt his own sanity and wonder how much of his revelation is bunk, due to neurological misfiring, neurons going haywire as a result of a simultaneously traumatic-yet-impossibly-uplifting religious experience driving him mad, as well as a lifetime of drug abuse.

Political intrigue. The Black Iron Prison — they killed JFK and they’re still going, and they’ve been alive and plotting (whether symbolically or literally) since Ancient Rome.

“Flow My Tears, the Policeman Said” being a prophesy and indictment of these evil figures, predicting a Second Civil War, the BLM riots and unrest against police (although also obviously alluding to the Black Panthers, leftist counterculture and anti-war protestors of his day, and hence plausibly rationalized), recreational drug use being widespread in future America, the age of consent being lowered to 12, genetic engineering creating a new caste system, ID2020 agenda being prefigured with all citizens required to have a government-issued ID card constantly checked at various police checkpoints, those without it thrown into forced labor camps, as happens to Jason Taverner in the book.

The struggle between automatism and awakening higher consciousness — the automatized masses do not like higher consciousness and persecute their own saints and sages (what happened to Socrates, Mansur al Hallaj, and Christ). Jetting out atonement theology in favor of a Gnostic view that Christ was crucified due to the misunderstanding and evil of humanity at large, and it is understanding and absorbing His message that is salvific, not just that He was “sacrificed” for us.

Gurdjieffian discussions in his Exegesis and in VALIS of seeing suffering or corrupt people (including himself at times, and especially before the experience) as malfunctioning, hay-wiring automata — the authentic religious experience as a transcendence of mechanicality and merciful release from Ananke (Necessity, Fate as a harsh, impersonally just overlord for the Ancient Greeks, as in their tragedies) or the Karma of the Dharmic religions.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Pinocchio-style-soteriology: turning from a mere puppet into a real human. Timothy Leary on humanity being a “cosmic larval intelligence” — dangerously still in the larval phase, note — and hence likely to fear or misunderstand “butterflies” transcending their chrysalis. The Supramental Ascent and Descent of the Hindu seer Sri Aurobindo (first rise in your Soul to the seeing and the knowing and the loving of Brahman, and then descend again to your lower spirit, psyche, emotions and body, to the world itself, and bring this light of Brahman to purify and pervade your entire individuality and share it with other people). The cosmic vision and worldviews of figures like Blake (engraving by him shown above) and Swedenborg, also highly religious yet falling outside the pale of orthodoxy.

The Black Iron Prison transformed for the survivors, the spiritually purified, into the Palm Tree Garden (which was secretly present all the time), like the New Jerusalem of the Book of Revelation or the enlightened kingdom of Shambhala depicted in the Tibetan Buddhist Kalachakra prophecies, instituted by Kalki (an incarnation of Vishnu) after he comes to defeat adharmic and asuric (demonic) forces on Earth, and ruled by the prophesied Maitreya Buddha.

A paradoxical parable on the limits of pseudo-intellectualism — PKD tries to create a grab-bag of all and sundry religions and philosophies (much like these very posts) but even this all-encompassing pseudo-theology can’t satisfy him and explain everything, just as endlessly talking about Bread is not the same as actually having or eating that Bread, like talking about Wine is still not being drunk with the Wine of the Sufis.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>21597223
KIMON LYCOS - PLATO ON JUSTICE AND POWER

The idea for this book would not have occurred to me if I had not been
confronted over a number of years with generations of puzzled, resisting, and,
even, irritated students. Though these were not the only responses to being
introduced to Plato's Republic, they were the most fruitful for me. For the probing
criticisms and imaginative suggestions of such students I am deeply grateful.
They made me realise that though the basic ideas in the Republic are clear enough,
what a modern audience finds somewhat difficult to grasp is the intellectual
motivation underlying the perspective on justice that inspires the work. It
gradually dawned on me that the best way of making this clear was through a
particular way of reading Book l-one which sought to bring forth its positive
force as a philosophical intervention in the socio-political climate of Plato's time.

If I was a Luddite I might say the anti-technological stance solves nearly every problem modern man is facing. Of course, these solutions are unacceptable to all the people who cannot survive without technology or do not believe they could live a good life without it. Surely a Luddite would argue that the psychological stress placed on humans in a technological system are so great that it will eventually fail, so the longer we delay anti-tech solutions the greater the disaster. The perils we endured with more primitive technologies were pains we evolved to suffer and endure. They were natural for us, and modern society is unnatural to us. The use of industrial technology prohibits us from expressing our natural behaviors in a similar way that animals in a zoo are stultified by their enclosures.

I think the best anti anything strategy is to talk to people. I'm not an authoritarian, so I wouldn't want to force anyone to do anything. Tactics and strategies assume a position of authority.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21587794
Nah just some playful joshing. The meter and rhyme are solid, just need a little fine-tuning so it scans better when read aloud. Ideally you shouldn't be dividing your lines with commas after every two or three words; just read aloud and see where they feel natural. Otherwise you run the risk of fatiguing the reader. Let your line breaks serve as moments of pause, they don't all need to end with a punctuation mark. Learning a little about enjambment will give your work a much stronger flow, especially when paired with a meter or rhyme scheme like what you're attempting here.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21587762
sincere poetry is always a bit awkward i dont want to discourage you. Still ...

There are too many repeating end-sounds that are either not rhyme or are slant. 'symphony' 'harmony' 'treachery' 'deity' where one or two can rhyme or resonate with one another and carry you through a poem, but this is just too many.

The imagery is also a bit stock. 'a stab in the back', 'a raw wound', 'shattered ruins' (the word shattered is used in almost every stanza ) are predictable. Use them more sparingly or better yet disguise them as something else. Poetry is the art of being clever in a short space and this is alot of the same things said over and over again .
Have a look at The Castaway by William rhyme . A famous poem about depression that only really lets on what it's about in the last 2 lines, a description of a failed sea voyage turns into a description of the human soul.

Also,an unfortunate fact of English poetry, close rhyme sounds funny. Now there are many, many exceptions to this, but it is generally true that close rhyme leads towards the comic. We are not Italians, we have to compensate for it. a stanza that rhymes 'heart' and 'heart' and then also as 'art', and 'depart' just cant help but leap of the tongue a little too quickly.

if you want more examples of depression poems have a look at Donne's Holy Sonnets, more Cowper, Swifts- Verses on the Death of Dr. Swift ( a comic poem), Pounds Pisan cantos, late Plath , Keat's Ode on Melancholy etc ... all deal with the subject in a much more carefully and usually in a roundabout way.

As i said i don't wish to discourage you, and wouldn't have written this if i didin't think you have some skill. Go and write something better because you can.

I'm a University student. A few weeks ago I had a revelation. I was unhappy. Incredibly so. I realized I was different from my peers. And the life assigned to me was not one I wished. I am a little over three and a half years into an Electrical Engineering degree from a prestigious Engineering school. I have recently dropped all my classes. Not only can I not stand them but since my inner change I cannot pass them. I went from being an excelling student to one who can no longer satisfy the course.

My internal revolution was that I want to become a Poet. I have begun taking introductory poetry courses and reading in my free time as well. I am not sure what degree I will attain at the end of this and I do not care. I can be given a General Studies degree. I do not care about these kinds of things.

I informed my family of this during a recent holiday. Their emotions ranged from enraged to confused. Even the most happy for me wondered how I would make money.

So what do you think? How can I devise a plan to make money from my passion? I no longer care about attaining Earthly possessions or high income. I just need to substantiate my independence to them.

posts.name: Frater Asemlen
posts.com:
Written awhile ago.

The Dark of mystery.

when the soft chant recalls distant days,
and the wrong path has lost you astray,
familiar once, now as through a maze,
then the dark limns its face, image fades,

as the dark limbs are swayed, insistent,
they grasp, you grasp, they pass, indiff’rent,
what is a glance to the limitless?
gone in the trance of the infinite.

as behind man’s eyes, the endless drifts,
whispered wisps mouthless, the sound of winds,
from out the throne of intelligence,
tongues-of-flame, from the profound abyss.

wind and flame is made my constant song,
when shade and mist are fled, darkness gone,
then the conscious longs, in its self longs,
itself wrong, it is gone, darkness dawns.

when its cold warmth is known by the lack,
there is but one world but this isn’t it,
sing neither the void nor maya’s dance,
both seen in the lake of listlessness.

frivolous each thought in synthesis,
both minimal and most intricate,
the pinnacle but an appearance,
but the visible part of spirit.

just as the swirled flame of skies azure,
or when the earthquakes and time obscures,
there when the world fades and I’m unsure,
is a conjured face mirror-contoured.

i am known when I am lost to self,
mind and soul is mine when gone to self,
like the foam when white and froths to self,
night is known when light is brought to self.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21595352
I really like your wordplay. "dark limns" then "dark limbs" (with limn's etymology making the first phrase tacitly oxymoronic); "limitless" and "infinite" put together, with "infinite" at the end (or, limit, finis) of a sentence; "lake" is followed eventually by "lack", which, for me, puts a spin on the meaning. There's a lot of good assonance throughout. I especially like the last stanza where the assonance on every stressed syllable makes itself very apparent, in light of the end-repetition of "self" (a repetition that would, in my view, be horrible, if not for the assonance preceding it; well written). It (the last stanza), to my ear, becomes (partially due to that assonance) very chant-like ("chant" is in the first line of the poem). I also think the title is fitting for the lack of any concrete imagery.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The original is in Portuguese

We must not gamble that we are like the Phoenix.
It is better to suspect that we are only chickens,
and that when death finally plucks us
our ashes will sleep the dreamless sleep of ashes,
in this world and the next, and will not be,
like the ashes of the Phoenix, just a nap of the fire.
See in life a beloved woman that you hug, grab, squeeze, kiss, lick, use and abuse,
a woman with whom you do everything the flesh dreams of in love,
until, when death comes, the sated soul and life, which was known to be loved,
will unravel, satisfied and happy,
like a blushing, sweaty, panting and smiling couple.
If that soul is now left with the dark, it will go to sleep peacefully,
but if an eternity actually exists, then that soul of yours will make the dead in paradise,
spoiled by paradisiacal things, wake up from their anesthesia
and celebrate your arrival with tears in their eyes,
fondly remembering - some for the first time - what they themselves were
when they were mortal.
Live to receive the tears of the dead as a gift.
Make your mortal life a wild wine so delicious that the Gods,
those sommeliers of the supreme,
will uselessly rummage through their celestial cellars
in search of wines of more ecstatic experiences.
Live in such a way as to make the Gods feel
that there is a tiny taste of boredom in their ecstasies.
That's my philosophy, and she tells me she is pleased to meet you.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>21597127
What do you mean? English original? If so, you really do whatever. The most common form is three lines that go from 5 syllables, to 7, back to five.
>First five syllables
>Next, use seven syllables
>And now five again
In Japanese there is a lot of extra complexity but most of it cannot be translated into English, so when you write haiku in English you can only really imitate things like cutting words/lines or themes. Sometimes rhyme is added when writing in English because it is otherwise extremely bland-- haiku doesn't work very well in other languages.

posts.name: Frater Asemlen
posts.com:
>>21597127

the actual haiku aesthetic is based on capturing a very subtle phenomena and experience, that at once communicate subtly, a relation between object and subject and most importantly transience.

So the haiku has to feel empty to imply the passing nature of things, because it’s based not in bright color or powerful harsh image but instead on much more subtle things such as a green leaf’s change of color, seeking out much isn’t appropriate.

Now you can simply dislike this style and there’s nothing wrong with that, but there is skill and mastery levels in this.

Example.


From time to time
The clouds give rest
To the moon-beholders.

(Note, Japanese doesn’t even count syllables so the 5-7-5 law is more us coping with not using the same metric system, so it’s fine to use similar short form, but there’s even authors who have incorporated the haiku style into long form prose.)

The first line puts our focus on time and on a passing event, the second line points to a natural object the clouds, themselves a symbol of transience, ever moving and changing, and in the third line the object fixation is transformed into the relation of an object in relation to a subject, the objects being the moon and cloud, the subject being the humans, the moon itself is a symbol of transience due to it having differing phases, thus the passing clouds, for a short amount of time covering the changing moon obscuring and for a time changing the perception of a human.

Basically every single syllable was used to amplify the imagery and conception of change, transience and ended perfectly in the relation of man to nature. That is why basho is a master of the haiku.


Note there are many which do not obey this much and many “free verse haiku” exist.

posts.name: Frater Asemlen
posts.com:
Flickering candle

as the wind blows I hear a melody,
flickers the dancing flames of candlelight,
and darkness balms my eyes in clemency,
so too mind moves to be self-analyzed.

marked was the many chains of entities,
the hierarchies that men made rhapsodized,
i knew them but an earthware effigy,
inscribed with words to which I’m acolyte.

half-mooned the light is harsh with levity,
the scintillating worlds men fantasized,
uncreated the light is heavenly,
but more so by illusions magnified.

venus thy finger is of ebony,
i hold the keys of basil valentine,
i know thou but the white wolf brevity,
and in thine hand the sickle saturnine.

sweet Knowledge of the worldly ecstasies,
this is the crest and signet palatine,
to sketch the stellar imaged destiny,
to trace the course of welkined satellites.

poisoned but needless of a remedy,
i know the apogee of appetite,
though in the flames and furies mentally,
nonetheless nothing less shall satisfy.

ah to the quickening of pregnancy,
each world to bursting birth and gratified,
to give its good a lasting legacy,
and to make its evils burn, sacrificed.

at last I spurn not the mind’s tendency,
at last the flickering flame pacified,
in peace to rest in darkness endlessly,
blazing divine this darkness, sanctified.

Whispers and murmurs echoes through the wires, the world of the
electron and the switch, the beauty of the baud. A light blue glow
radiating. The transformers constant hum, inaudible distant voices.

Outside the rave talking, you hear distant voices, music muddled by
the bass bleeding through the walls. Time is moving slow. In the
background people laughing, loud voices, confrontations, discussions,
things are happening, speed up but slowed down. Warm summer night
walking through the empty city. Like a factory at night, assembly
lines stand still, that which once was busy, now powered off.

Twenty year old conversations, frozen in time, paused, trails of
someone long gone. The future looking back, alone, finds comfort in
the past. During the night, in the distant past, time stands still.
The ever present chatter, intersecting agencies and the incomprehensibly
chaotic movement, asleep, revealing what remains and what really is.

Whirlwinds of static humming
Bounce photons off melodies
That cull will’s grand striving
Torn from detestable perching

Circuitry signs the morphing age
Harmonious shackles gel avatars
And avatars rend angels’ flesh
Apologists hook their fanged barbs
While vultures pluck the omniscient
For his comforting lies of close heat
Entrusting their proximity as sacred
Dangerously absorb fractal reflection
Man’s loneliness flees to his bosom
To find smoke and staunch blackness
Cores and mechanical revolutionaries
Swirl around hazy vapor remembrances
Of wolves stalking outside hamlets
And pilgrims trudging towards pyres
Which remain only as flickering embers
Dashed and stomped by nobility
In towers made from records kept
The chain expands and grips to all
Removal attempts quickens the capture
Dissipated instructions lies dormant

>Is this what it's like to get "pilled?"
Yes. As to your question, you're exhibiting a fatalistic mindset. There are people with one of two beliefs regarding their relationship with the world; the first has an external locus control in which the future is a series of uncontrollable events that happen to a person, i.e., what will happen was always going to happen regardless of the actions I take, and the second an internal locus in which the future is controllable and dirigible by his actions, i.e., what will happen is determined by the actions I take. People with the former tend towards fatalistic thinking and I speculate are higher neuroticism than the latter.

Let's roll the dice however. As you are (being) fatalistic, I'll say this whatever you do and wherever you are sorted will be sorted out after you have done it. Fatalism has a positive form where you take action because you believe that you were fated to do so. So if you wish to write, then write. You were meant to, after all, right?

Finally, striving and excellence are a struggle and largely ambiguous. They will always be so. If you don't believe it's worth it, then don't pursue it.

>>21585665
Spengler was wrong about decline. He correctly identified the process but it never occurred to him that every civilization might decline differently. His diagnosis of Western decline is the same as his diagnosis of Classical decline. This makes no sense.

It makes perfect sense that the static and ahistorical civilization of antiquity would end as he describes, in a frozen terminal state, but it makes no sense that the dynamic and moving civilization of the West would end the same way. He's already been proven wrong about the terminal state of Western art by modern film and music, art which never ossified like late Roman art did.

Western art in its "decline" just continues on forever, the only difference is it's not this big monocultural entity that it was in the 15th to 19th centuries. It's perfectly fine to still be an artist if you want.

Spengler's own pessimism massively distorted what could have been a perfect model of civilization cycles. Don't get dragged into it.

Spengler isn't really a "cyclic" thinker in that regard, as the cycles are what WE, the humans, are subjected to, but the Culture-Civilizations are absolutely not cyclic, they're entirely linear.

My understanding is that Jupiter is not a symbol of "the unlimited" but rather of eternal expansion and elevation, which is slightly different. I do think that it would be interesting to see which traditional planet is attributed with the negative phenomenon of pride/arrogance.
As to the reason why Saturn is associated with limit, I think it has to do with two things. First, Saturn is the dimmest planet in the sky. It carries connotations of weakness, endings, the expending of strength and finality. Second, Saturn is traditionally the most external planet - if Earth is the centre, and all the other planets form concentric circles around this circle, Saturn is the final circle, the edge of the cosmos. It marks the outer limit and the end of life and light, both celestial and human. Further, as a symbol of the outer limit, it is also a symbol of time and death, hence why Saturn was also known as Kronos or the star of Kronos. Everything exists and lives on its appropriate plane, and carries on its journey, until the very end, at which point Saturn collects what is due and dispenses death - the meaning of the life is therefore forced to be constrained within a beginning and an end, giving mortal beings a kind of imperative to attend to our tasks, needs and duties - this is why Saturn is the lord of organisation, control, discipline, mastery and authority, in addition to being a lord of disaster, pain, suffering and death.

those are synonymous terms. Saturn is limit, and associated with contraction (esoterically).
